data: Print the string 'Discode is fun!' 100 times.
expected_solution: function main(){for(let i=0 ; i<100; i++){console.log('Discode is fun!');}}

data: You are given a string, print 'Yes' if it is equal to 'hello' , otherwise print 'No'.

You are given three numbers: the minimum value of a range, the maximum value of a range, and a specific value. Print 'Yes' if the value falls within the range (including the minimum and maximum values), otherwise print 'No'.
expected_solution: function main(min, max, value) { if(min <= value && value <= max){ console.log('Yes');} else { console.log('No');}}

data: You are given two numbers. Print their sum.
You are given an array and an index. If the index is not within the range of the array, print 'Error'. Otherwise, print the value at this index.
expected_solution: function main(index) { const arr = ['chocolate', 'candey' , 'pizza' , 'pasta']; if(index < 0 || index >= arr.length) {console.log('Error');} else {console.log(arr[index]);}}

data: You are given a length. Build an array containing numbers from 0 to the given length (including the length). At the end, print the resulting array.
expected_solution: function main(length) { const arr = []; for(let i=0; i<=length; i++){ arr[i] = i;} console.log(arr); }

data: You are given an array containing prices of toys you want to buy, as well as the amount of money you have. Print ':)' if you can afford to buy all those items with your money. Otherwise, print ':('.
expected_solution: function main(money) { const arr = [20, 40 ,50, 70, 5]; var sum = 0; for(let i=0; i<arr.length; i++) {sum = sum + arr[i];} if(sum <= money) {console.log(':)'); } else {console.log(':(');} }

data: Use a while loop to print all numbers from 5 to 100 in jumps of 5.
expected_solution: function main() { var count = 5; while(count <=100) {console.log(count); count = count + 5;}}

data: Iterate over all the numbers from 1 to 10 and print the number i, repeated i times.
expected_solution: function main() { for(let i=1; i<=10; i++){ for(let j=0; j<i; j++) {console.log(i);}}}

data: Write a function that takes a string as input and prints the reversed version of the string. At the end, print the resulting string.
expected_solution: function main(string) { let reversedString = ''; for(let i=string.length-1; i>=0; i--){ reversedString += string[i];} console.log(reversedString);}

data: You receive two numbers and a sign that can be '-', '+', '/', or '*', build a calculator using a switch case. If the sign is not one of those options print 'Error', otherwise print the solution.
expected_solution: function main(num1,num2,sign) { switch(sign) { case '-': console.log(num1-num2); break; case '+': console.log(num1+num2); break; case '*': console.log(num1*num2); break; case '/': console.log(num1/num2); break; default: console.log('Error');}}
